discussion.content:
should answer should be PEAP... 
WPS does not require authentication except a push of a button, TKIP and PKI is all about encryption
PEAP should be the correct answer

comments.content:
WPS - only PIN
PEAP - Authentication - https://i.stack.imgur.com/tjxCD.png
TKIP - Encryption
PKI - Public key Infra (not User name and pass)

discussion.content: Set authentication information for using TTLS or PEAP with IEEE802.1X authentication. TTLS and PEAP perform mutual authentication using the authentication server's certificate and the user name and password PEAP is correct
PEAP! WPS should be disabled!!!

WPS???? Really??? Even before I started studying for sec+ I have used WPS to connect to the WiFi by using an 8 digit pin by pushing the button but never I entered a username. Someone, please kill this man who is writing all these stupid answers
Question has no adequate details to figure out which is right answer ! I go with PEAP

comments.content: WPS doesn't require a username, so A is wrong

discussion.content: WPS stands for WiFi Protected Setup, and its purpose is to make a connection between a wireless device and a router a lot easier. This technology will only work with wireless networks that require a password and are encrypted with the security protocols WPA Personal or WPA2.
This is PEAP.
PEAP is correct
PEAP my dudes

An organization is struggling to differentiate threats from normal traffic and access to systems. A security engineer has been asked to recommend a system that will aggregate data and provide metrics that will assist in identifying malicious actors or other anomalous activity throughout the environment. Which of the following solutions should the engineer recommend?

discussion.content:
Key word “ aggregate data ”
Answer is correct

comments.content:
Your answer helped me learn this question, thanks. 
Now when I see aggregate data, I see SIEM.

discussion.content: SIEM software combines security information management (SIM) and security event management (SEM) to provide real-time analysis of security alerts generated by applications and network hardware.
Aggregation. SIEM platforms collect data from thousands of different sources because these events provide the data we need to analyze the health and security of our environment.
aggregate data and provide metrics that will assist in identifying malicious actors or other anomalous activity throughout the environment<<<.>>>> this is the clue for the answer

choices.B: The security of the application relies on antivirus.
choices.A: The integrity of the data is at risk.
choices.D: The application is vulnerable to race conditions.

discussion.content:
Protecting yourself from a hybrid attack
It's not difficult to predict that you, like so many other people, are going to use a year in your password, and neither is the fact that you'll place it either at the end or in the beginning. The same goes for capitalizing the first letter of your password or putting an exclamation mark at the end.

If your password is to be resistant to a hybrid attack, it needs to be random. You have to make sure that cybercrooks can't guess what it consists of. In fact, ideally, even you shouldn’t know what your password consists of.
XSS attacks. Others don't make sense so just use process of elimination.
A, JavaScript big data integrity risk.
I used Javascript to make sure the form is being filled out with proper info in the name, address, e-mail, etc before submitting the form.
Javascript uses Plaintext so this is a very big risk for data integrity.
All other answers don't make sense. Antivirus not necessary, host based firewall unnecessary too and race conditions are caused by poor programming... I sit my sec+ next week. Any pointers?
Anyone knows why it is A ?

comments.content: Javascript is used for XSS thus exposing data
Close, if it’s using js to validate, it means it’s probably validating on the client side, not server side

questions.question_text: Which of the following occurs when the security of a web application relies on JavaScript for input validation?

discussion.content:
The key difference between SSO and FIM is while SSO is designed to authenticate a single credential across various systems within one organization, federated identity management systems offer single access to a number of applications across various enterprises.

Source: https://www.okta.com/identity-101/federated-identity-vs-sso/#:~:text=The%20key%20difference%20between%20SSO,of%20applications%20across%20various%20enterprises.
Key phrase is "multiple enterprises". Thus, Federation is the best answer (over SSO).
Think of it as using your google credentials to login to your facebook account. Same credentials, multiple enterprises.
Correct answer

questions.question_text: The concept of connecting a user account across the systems of multiple enterprises is BEST known as:

discussion.content: RAID 0 is offers no redundancy as it only splits the data. RAID 1 on the other hand, mirrors the data therefore providing true redundancy.

Just are refresher of types of RAID

Redundancy:
RAID 0 – does not provide fault tolerance/ all space is available for data storage
RAID 1 – stores same data on both drives/ two 400gb drives = 400gb available for storage
RAID 5 – reserves on drive for parity/ four 400gb drives = 1200 for space/ 4 x 4 – 400 = 1200
RAID 6 – reserves two drives for parity/ four 400gb drives = 800 for space/ 4 x 4 - 800 = 800
Maximum Drives for Redundancy:
RAID 0 – 2 or more/ 3 500gb drives = 1500 available for space
RAID 1 – 2 drives/ single point of failure/ if one fail, other drive still works
RAID 5 – 3 or more/ striping w/ parity (same example below)/ 1 drive allowable for lost data
RAID 6 – 4 or more/ 1 disk taken (ex. 4 400gb = 1600gb - -400 gb)/ 2 drives allowed for lost data
RAID 1 consists of an exact copy (or mirror) of a set of data on two or more disks; a classic RAID 1 mirrored pair contains two disks.
